Also, patinated "shakudo" alloys were used in the Middle East as early as
the 19th C BCE.

Jim
---------

Jim and all,

It is interesting to see the geographic connections, especially since the
Japanese "invented" all of these techniques and motifs, right? (Reminds me
of the Greeks, the Italians, etc.) See part of "Lies My Teachers Taught Me"
by Bob Haynes in the most recent To-Ron for further comments along these
lines.

I just saw an Indian dagger in the Asian Art Museum in San Francisco that
had gold inlay on the blade done this way no doubt, actually in the kind of
tendril designs we see so often on Japanese metalwork. It had a walrus ivory
handle, a very attractive item. Unfortunately my notes on it's date and
place are temporarily inaccessible, and my digital camera batteries died
just after I got to the museum.

Craig Harris
